thread.title: AL.com instant analysis: Alabama overcomes Texas A&M surge, pulls off big win
thread.title_full: AL.com instant analysis: Alabama overcomes Texas A&M surge, pulls off big win | AL.com

author: Matt Zenitz | mzenitz@al.com
title: AL.com instant analysis: Alabama overcomes Texas A&M surge, pulls off big win
text:
The momentum had shifted in Texas A&M's favor in the third quarter.
The Aggies got a 68-yard punt return for a touchdown from Christian Kirk to cut Alabama's lead to 15 late in the second quarter. The Tide's lead was down to eight after a 3-yard touchdown pass from Kyle Allen to Ricky Seals-Jones early in the third quarter. A blocked punt following an Alabama three-and-out then gave the Aggies the ball at the Tide's 29-yard line with a chance at a tying touchdown.
Texas A&M players had a noticeable bounce while the crowd inside Kyle Field was as loud as it had been the entire game.
From there, Alabama held on and pulled away for a 41-23 win.
Texas A&M failed to gain a yard on the drive that could have produced a tying touchdown. The Tide got a field goal from Adam Griffith on the ensuing possession. Another Griffith field goal had Alabama back up by 14 early in the fourth quarter.
Freshman cornerback Minkah Fitzpatrick essentially sealed the win midway through the fourth quarter with an interception he returned 55 yards for a touchdown to push the Tide's lead to 41-23.
Game-changer at safety
Tide safety Eddie Jackson had two momentum-shifting plays.
With Texas A&M driving midway through the second quarter and down just 21-6, Jackson intercepted Allen and returned the ball 93 yards for a touchdown.
He had another interception late in the third quarter with the Tide up 31-20.
The interception and 26-yard return set Alabama up at Texas A&M's 28-yard line.
That put the Tide in position for the Griffith field goal that extended their lead to 34-20.
After moving from cornerback to safety during the spring, Jackson has five interceptions, two interception returns for touchdowns and a forced fumble that he recovered in his first seven games at safety.
Big-play freshman
Fitzpatrick had two pick-sixes.
He was responsible for the game's first points, intercepting Allen midway through the first quarter and returning the ball 33 yards for a touchdown.
He then had the second pick-six during the fourth quarter.
Leading the way
While Alabama running back Derrick Henry was limited to a degree after the Tide's first drive of the second quarter, Henry was a big part of Alabama jumping out to an early 21-6 lead.
Henry's previous career-high for rushing yards in a game was 148. He ran for 153 yards and a touchdown on nine carries during the first quarter Saturday.
He added a 6-yard touchdown on his first carry of the second quarter.
Henry finished with 236 yards and the two touchdowns on 32 carries.
He also had an 18-yard catch-and-run.
Bad day for special teams
Kirk had the punt return for a touchdown.
The Aggies blocked a punt.
In addition, usually reliable Tide punt returner Cyrus Jones had a fumble that was recovered by Texas A&M.
One of the positives for Alabama special teams-wise? Griffith, who has struggled but was 2 of 2 on field goals Saturday.
Uneven game for the secondary
While Alabama had the four interceptions and three pick-sixes, Texas A&M's quarterbacks — Allen and Kyler Murray — threw for a combined 284 yards.
